verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Narrative introduction, as in Hebrew; the speaker is specified.

verses.text: Speak to all the congregation of the people of Israel, and say to them, 'You must be holy, for I, the LORD your God, am holy.'
verses.comment: This verse forms the central command for the chapter. 'Must be holy' reflects the imperative nature.

verses.text: Each one of you must respect his mother and his father, and you shall keep my Sabbaths. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: 'Respect' translates 'fear' (יִרְאָה), meaning reverent respect.

verses.text: Do not turn to idols, and do not make for yourselves molten gods. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: 'Molten gods' means idols cast from metal.

verses.text: When you offer a sacrifice of peace offerings to the LORD, you shall offer it so that you may be accepted.
verses.comment: 'Accepted' means according to God’s laws for such sacrifices.

verses.text: It must be eaten on the day you offer it, and the next day; but anything left until the third day must be burned with fire.
verses.comment: The eating period for peace offerings aligns exactly with previous legislation.

verses.text: If it is eaten on the third day, it is a disgusting thing; it will not be accepted.
verses.comment: 'Disgusting thing' renders the term 'abomination.'

verses.text: Everyone who eats it will bear his iniquity, because he has profaned what is holy to the LORD; that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: 'Cut off' may mean excommunication or death; see note.

verses.text: When you reap the harvest of your land, you must not reap your field to its very edge, nor gather the gleanings of your harvest.
verses.comment: 'Gleanings' are leftover crops.

verses.text: You must not strip your vineyard bare, nor gather the fallen grapes of your vineyard; you shall leave them for the poor and for the foreigner. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: 'Foreigner' is the resident alien (ger).

verses.text: You shall not steal. You shall not deal falsely. You shall not lie to one another.
verses.comment: Direct commands, all second person.

verses.text: You shall not swear falsely by my name, so as to profane the name of your God; I am the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Profane' means to treat as common or unholy.

verses.text: You shall not oppress your neighbor, nor rob him. The wages of a hired worker must not remain with you all night until the morning.
verses.comment: Employers commanded to pay wages promptly.

verses.text: You shall not curse the deaf, nor put a stumbling block before the blind, but you shall fear your God. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Cursing or causing harm to disabled persons is forbidden.

verses.text: You shall do no injustice in judgment. You shall not be partial to the poor nor show favoritism to the great, but in righteousness you shall judge your neighbor.
verses.comment: No partiality is an essential aspect of biblical justice.

verses.text: You shall not go about as a slanderer among your people, and you shall not stand against the life of your neighbor. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Stand against' means 'endanger,' e.g. in court.

verses.text: You shall not hate your brother in your heart, but you shall reason frankly with your neighbor, lest you incur sin because of him.
verses.comment: 'Reason frankly' renders 'surely rebuke.'

verses.text: You shall not take vengeance or bear a grudge against the sons of your people, but you shall love your neighbor as yourself. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Love your neighbor as yourself' is as directly as the Hebrew allows.

verses.text: You shall keep my statutes. You shall not let your livestock breed with a different kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed; and you shall not wear a garment made of two kinds of material mixed together.
verses.comment: All three laws relate to God’s principle of separation.

verses.text: If a man lies with a woman who is a slave, betrothed to another man, but not yet ransomed or set free, there must be an investigation. They shall not be put to death, because she was not free.
verses.comment: Reflects nuances about slavery and betrothal in context.

verses.text: He shall bring his guilt offering to the LORD, to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, a ram as a guilt offering.
verses.comment: The man alone bears responsibility for the sacrifice.

verses.text: And the priest shall make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering before the LORD for his sin that he has committed, and he will be forgiven for his sin which he has committed.
verses.comment: Priestly atonement is necessary for forgiveness.

verses.text: When you come into the land and plant any kind of tree for food, you shall regard its fruit as forbidden. For three years it shall be forbidden to you; it shall not be eaten.
verses.comment: 'Forbidden' translates 'uncircumcised.'

verses.text: But in the fourth year all its fruit shall be holy, an offering of praise to the LORD.
verses.comment: In the fourth year, fruit is for God in a special way.

verses.text: In the fifth year you may eat of its fruit, to increase its yield for you. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: The pattern expresses devotion and blessing.

verses.text: You shall not eat any flesh with the blood in it. You shall not practice divination or seek omens.
verses.comment: 'Divination' and 'seek omens' are occult practices.

verses.text: You shall not round off the hair on the sides of your heads, nor mar the edges of your beard.
verses.comment: A reference to mourning customs for the dead.

verses.text: You shall not make cuts in your flesh for the dead or tattoo any marks upon yourselves. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Tattoo' is literal; context is pagan mourning.

verses.text: Do not profane your daughter by making her a prostitute, so that the land does not become guilty of prostitution and filled with wickedness.
verses.comment: Prostitution forbidden; linked to land's purity.

verses.text: You shall keep my Sabbaths and reverence my sanctuary. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Sabbath and temple practices linked often in Leviticus.

verses.text: Do not turn to mediums or to those who consult familiar spirits. Do not seek them out, so as to be made unclean by them. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: 'Familiar spirits' refers to necromancers, as context shows.

verses.text: You shall rise up before the gray-haired and honor the face of an old man, and you shall fear your God. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Respect for elders is closely tied to piety.

verses.text: When a foreigner resides with you in your land, you shall not oppress him.
verses.comment: 'Foreigner' (ger) means a resident alien.

verses.text: The foreigner who resides with you shall be as the native among you, and you shall love him as yourself, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Love for the stranger directly equated to native neighbor.

verses.text: You shall do no injustice in judgment, in measures of length or weight or quantity.
verses.comment: Weights and measures are judicially important.

verses.text: You shall have honest balances, honest weights, honest measures of dry volume and liquid volume. I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Ephah = dry; hin = liquid measure.

verses.text: So you shall keep all my statutes and all my rules, and do them. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Summary: all the LORD’s commands must be obeyed.
